title: Prince Roderick Greymont
atAGlance:
**Prince Roderick Greymont** - Crown Prince, Heir to the Throne, "The Young Lion"

- Eldest son of King Aldric, will inherit the Kingdom
- Warrior prince‚Äîbrave, bold, and eager for glory
- Wants to attack Veraheim and prove human supremacy
- Popular with soldiers, less so with courtiers
- *Common saying: "The Prince fights like a lion and thinks like one too."*

| | |
|---|---|
| **Age** | 28 |
| **Role** | Crown Prince |
| **Status** | Unmarried (major political issue) |
| **Disposition** | Aggressive |
| **Threat Level** | Medium (currently); High (when King) |

---
commonKnowledge:
### Appearance & Manner
Tall, broad-shouldered, warrior's build. Handsome in an aggressive way. Dark hair worn longer than his father likes. Mother's green eyes, but harder. Dresses martially‚Äîalways ready for a fight. Confident posture, direct gaze, firm handshake that's slightly too firm.

### Personality
Brave to the point of recklessness. Impatient with politics and scheming. Believes firmly in human supremacy‚Äînon-humans are lesser beings to him. Charismatic with soldiers, awkward with courtiers. Short temper, holds grudges. Wants to be a conqueror-king like the legends.

### Family Tensions
Constant conflict with his father over policy. Roderick thinks Aldric's diplomacy is weakness. He wants action: attack Veraheim, push back the elves, expand human dominion. Aldric keeps restraining him, which Roderick resents deeply.

### Public Activities
- Trains constantly, often with the Royal Guard
- Attends tournaments, usually wins
- Drinks with Lord Eisenwald and Lord Blackthorne
- Gives speeches about human glory that soldiers love
- Avoids council meetings when possible

### Marriage Situation
At 28, still unmarried‚Äîunusual for a Crown Prince. Every Lord wants the connection. Father keeps delaying, citing "finding the right match." Roderick doesn't care about marriage; he cares about glory.

---
secretKnowledge:
### True Nature
Roderick is not stupid‚Äîhe's impatient and ideologically blinded. He genuinely believes humans are superior and that strength is the only virtue that matters. He loves his father but can't respect his methods. He desperately wants Aldric's approval and will never admit it.

### The Father Wound
Deep down, Roderick knows he disappoints his father. Aldric rarely praises him. Every political lecture feels like criticism. Roderick responds by doubling down on what he's good at (fighting) and rejecting what he's bad at (politics). This is slowly destroying their relationship.

### Dangerous Influences
- **Lord Eisenwald:** Cultivating Roderick, teaching him that military strength is true power. Wants Roderick to remember his "friends" when he's King.
- **Lord Blackthorne:** Drinking companion, feeding Roderick's worst impulses. Edmund sees Roderick as a useful tool‚Äîan aggressive King is easier to manipulate.
- **The Military Faction:** Young officers who share his views, forming a faction that will support him when he takes power.

### The Veraheim Obsession
Roderick genuinely believes attacking Veraheim would be:
- Glorious (reclaiming human dominion)
- Easy (it's just one city)
- Popular (everyone secretly wants it)

He's wrong on all counts. Vera's magic, Thorongil's power, and the Broken Isles alliance would crush any assault. Aldric knows this; Roderick won't listen.

### What He Actually Wants
- His father's respect (will never admit this)
- To be remembered as a great king
- Military glory and conquest
- To prove human supremacy through action

### What He Fears
- Being seen as weak
- Becoming his father (a "mere" politician)
- Never getting his chance at glory
- That his father might be right

### When He Becomes King
If Aldric dies and Roderick takes the throne:
- He'll likely attack Veraheim within the first year
- He'll promote the military Lords (Eisenwald, Wolfstein)
- He'll sideline the political Lords (Belmont, K√∂nigsford)
- Edmund Blackthorne will have significant influence
- The Kingdom may not survive his reign

### Story Hooks

| Hook | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **The Reckless Plan** | Roderick is planning something without his father's knowledge. Stop him or help him? |
| **The Prince's Favor** | Roderick takes interest in the PCs. His patronage comes with expectations. |
| **Father and Son** | Aldric asks the PCs to moderate Roderick. Roderick asks them to help him act. |
| **The Wrong Friends** | Evidence that Blackthorne is manipulating Roderick. Does the Prince believe it? |
| **Succession** | Aldric dies. Roderick is now King. Everything changes. |
